body_html:
Pretty sure this is another bug in SliceHelper. Probably in the first if condition when iterating over the slice objects. I'll try to take a look later.
…
On Sat, Jul 8, 2017, 6:47 PM Andrew Selle ***@***.***> wrote: It is known that int 64 index support is not well supported in many of our ops. the workaround is to cast to tf.int32 (with tf.cast) or in this case since it is a constant use tf.int32. If you are using over 2 billion entry tensors, then you might need to work on adding the support. @vrv <https://github.com/vrv>, has some ideas on how to handle this more elegantly. — You are receiving this because you were mentioned.  ops. the workaround is to cast to tf.int32 (with tf.cast) or in this case
 since it is a constant use tf.int32. If you are using over 2 billion entry

body:
Pretty sure this is another bug in SliceHelper. Probably in the first if
condition when iterating over the slice objects. I'll try to take a look
later.

On Sat, Jul 8, 2017, 6:47 PM Andrew Selle <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> It is known that int 64 index support is not well supported in many of our
> ops. the workaround is to cast to tf.int32 (with tf.cast) or in this case
> since it is a constant use tf.int32. If you are using over 2 billion entry
> tensors, then you might need to work on adding the support. @vrv
> <https://github.com/vrv>, has some ideas on how to handle this more
> elegantly.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/11380#issuecomment-313892044>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAcTeXgm0y8G1BPTi4lMIxu1T6y6w93Pks5sMDE8gaJpZM4ORxaF>
> .
